javaslang.test

Interface Arbitrary<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the arbitrary object.
    All Superinterfaces:
    FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>, Iterable<T>, Kind<Arbitrary<?>,T>, TraversableOnce<T>
    Functional Interface:
    This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.

    @FunctionalInterface
public interface Arbitrary<T>
extends TraversableOnce<T>, FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>, Kind<Arbitrary<?>,T>
    Represents an arbitrary object of type T.
    Since:
    1.2.0

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        Gen<T> apply(int size)

        Returns a generator for objects of type T. Use Gen.map(Function) and Gen.flatMap(Function) to combine object generators.

        Example:

         
 // represents arbitrary binary trees of a certain depth n
 final class ArbitraryTree implements Arbitrary<BinaryTree<Integer>> {
     @Override
     public Gen<BinaryTree<Integer>> apply(int n) {
         return Gen.choose(-1000, 1000).flatMap(value -> {
                  if (n == 0) {
                      return Gen.of(BinaryTree.leaf(value));
                  } else {
                      return Gen.frequency(
                              Tuple.of(1, Gen.of(BinaryTree.leaf(value))),
                              Tuple.of(4, Gen.of(BinaryTree.branch(apply(n / 2).get(), value, apply(n / 2).get())))
                      );
                  }
         });
     }
 }

 // tree generator with a size hint of 10
 final Gen<BinaryTree<Integer>> treeGen = new ArbitraryTree().apply(10);

 // stream sum of tree node values to console for 100 arbitrary trees
 Stream.of(() -> treeGen.apply(RNG.get())).map(Tree::sum).take(100).stdout();
        Parameters:
        size - A (not necessarily positive) size parameter which may be interpreted idividually and is constant for all arbitrary objects regarding one property check.
        Returns:
        A generator for objects of type T.

      • filter

        default Arbitrary<T> filter(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Returns an Arbitrary based on this Arbitrary which produces values that fulfill the given predicate.
        Specified by:
        filter in interface FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>
        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        A new generator

      • filterOption

        default Arbitrary<Some<T>> filterOption(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Returns a new FilterMonadic consisting of Some elements if there are elements which satisfy the given predicate. Otherwise the results contains one None element. Please note, that the result will not contain a mixture of Some and None elements.

        This method is intended to be used with monadic types which may have only one value, e.g. Lazy and Match (resp. MatchMonad).

        Specified by:
        filterOption in interface FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>
        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        a new FilterMonadic instance

      • flatMap

        Maps arbitrary objects T to arbitrary object U.

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • flatMapM

        default <U> Arbitrary<U> flatMapM(Function<? super T,? extends Kind<? extends Arbitrary<?>,? extends U>> mapper)
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Flat maps the elements of this elements of a new type preserving their order, if any.

        This method effectively does call 

        this.flatMap((Function<? super T, ? extends M<? extends U>>) mapper);
        It exists, because Java's type system (the lack of higher-order kinds) does not allow us to define an interface containing the mentioned flatMap method.
        Specified by:
        flatMapM in interface FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - Component type of the flat mapped FilterMonadic
        Parameters:
        mapper - A mapper.
        Returns:
        a flat mapped FilterMonadic

      • flatten

        default Arbitrary<Object> flatten()
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Flattens a FilterMonadic.

        The semantics may vary from class to class. The commonality is, that some kind of wrapped state is recursively unwrapped.

        Example: 

        ((1, 2), 3, (4, (5, 6))).flatten() = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
        Specified by:
        flatten in interface FilterMonadic<Arbitrary<?>,T>
        Returns:
        A flattened version of this FilterMonadic.

      • peek

        default Arbitrary<T> peek(Consumer<? super T> action)
        Description copied from interface: TraversableOnce
        Performs the given action on the first element if this is an eager implementation. Performs the given action on all elements (the first immediately, successive deferred), if this is a lazy implementation.
        Specified by:
        peek in interface TraversableOnce<T>
        Parameters:
        action - The action the will be performed on the element(s).
        Returns:
        this instance

      • string

        static Arbitrary<String> string(Gen<Character> gen)

        Generates arbitrary strings based on a given alphabet represented by gen.

        Example:

         
 Arbitrary.string(
     Gen.frequency(
         Tuple.of(1, Gen.choose('A', 'Z')),
         Tuple.of(1, Gen.choose('a', 'z')),
         Tuple.of(1, Gen.choose('0', '9'))));
        Parameters:
        gen - A character generator
        Returns:
        a new Arbitrary of String

      • list

        static <T> Arbitrary<List<T>> list(Arbitrary<T> arbitraryT)

        Generates arbitrary lists based on a given element generator arbitraryT.

        Example:

         
 Arbitrary.list(Arbitrary.integer());
        Type Parameters:
        T - Component type of the List
        Parameters:
        arbitraryT - Arbitrary elements of type T
        Returns:
        a new Arbitrary of List<T>
